awd_titl_txt: Parsed and Audio-Aligned Corpus of Bilingual Russian Child Speech (BiRCh)
awd_abstract_narration:
Language, thought, and culture are intricately connected, but the way this relationship plays out over the lifespan of an individual, especially a bilingual person, is not well understood.  Bilinguals constitute a large portion of the US population and around the world. This project researches the language of bilingual speakers in Russian immigrant communities to gain a better understanding of fundamental properties of linguistic knowledge, language acquisition and maintenance, the nature of language variation and change, and stability of native speaker knowledge.  Studying the language of immigrants is also important, because it will help build understanding and respect for these often stigmatized linguistic practices. The large, open-access database of bilingual and monolingual Russian speech created during the project will allow education policy makers and practitioners to make appropriate decisions concerning bilingual children in American schools and to create educational resources for heritage speakers of Russian who are an invaluable language resource for the country. Ultimately, this database can also help natural language processing applications for Russian, such as enhancing opportunities for cross-cultural communication online, and making new and less available publications quickly accessible through summarization and machine translation.

The project will construct an open-access online database documenting the speech of two types of bilinguals: émigré adults and young bilingual children in Russian-speaking families in the US and Germany, with a control group of monolingual families with small children in Russia.  This first-of-its-kind database will serve as a tool for comparing linguistic behavior across populations and over time, investigating correlations between grammatical, lexical, and sociolinguistic variables. It will contain audio-aligned transcripts and will be annotated for morphology (e.g., "feminine noun") and syntax (e.g., "relative clause"), which will allow researchers to study frequencies of constructions in both the parents' and children's speech.  The database will enable researchers to tease apart several possible causes of the differences between the home language of bilingual children and adults, and the speech of monolinguals: normal processes of language change or the influence of the majority language and culture; incomplete learning or forgetting of the home language; or universal cognitive and linguistic principles.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of the BiRCh project was to investigate acquisition of Russian in immigrant communities in North America and Germany, in order to disentangle the role of language input, incomplete acquisition, majority language, and attrition in bilingual language development. We first created a corpus of speech produced by bilingual children acquiring Russian in the USA and Canada and Germany, and monolingual children in the Russian Federation and Ukraine for comparison. This one-million-word corpus traces language acquisition of children 2-7 years old through recordings of naturalistic interactions between children and their parents. 

The BiRCh corpus contains audio recordings and time-aligned transcripts annotated for bilingual phenomena and speech disfluencies, such as mid-sentence switches to another language or false starts. Each word is annotated for part of speech and its characteristics (e.g., grammatical gender, number, and case), and each utterance is parsed (i.e., each phrase is assigned a syntactic role). BiRCh also includes detailed sociolinguistic interviews with participating families. 

Once the first annotated data became available, we launched the following research projects which are expanding now that the full corpus is available; their results will be published upon completion. 

Disfluencies/discourse markers: In a small BiRCh subcorpus of parental speech, we observed that even though parents across the 3 groups often used two interjections (“aa” and “mm”) as pause fillers, they also had other functions (e.g. call for attention), i.e., they behave somewhat like words. Differences between population groups showed that “aa” and “mm” could signal processing difficulties for bilinguals. False starts and the pause-filling “aa” and “mm” were correlated for bilingual, but not monolingual adults. This points to the effect of bilingualism: Émigré parents can plausibly have higher processing load due to activation of their other language, more costly lexical retrieval, or possibly lower active vocabulary in Russian. 

Acquisition of polite requests: Continuing our prior research on polite requests in adult heritage speakers (HSs) of Russian, we analyzed utterances with “po�alujsta” (please) in a BiRCh subcorpus. Previously, we identified that adult HSs use a combination of the impersonal modal “mo�no” (possible) and “po�alujsta” to mark politeness in requests for favor, but this combination is not used in homeland Russian outside one specific construction. The preliminary results of the BiRCh-based study confirm that this combination is frequently used by both bilingual adults and children, with the Russian American families using it the most, and monolingual families in our corpus never used it. We are now comparing data on bilingual children with their parents and with monolingual speakers.

Passives. Russian has 2 types of passives: perfective participial passives (“byl postroen” [was built]) and imperfective passives with the suffix “sja” (“stroilsja” [was being built]). This suffix also has many other functions. Prior scholarship shows that passives are acquired relatively late by monolingual Russian children, and the two passive constructions are acquired differently. There is evidence for the loss of most “sja” forms and both types of passives in low-proficiency adult Russian HSs.  

In our BiRCh-based pilot study, we first analyzed different functions of “sja” in the corpus and compared the frequency of this suffix in child and parental speech. We are in the process of comparing the passive uses of “sja” with participial passives to understand the lexical, grammatical, and cognitive factors influencing the acquisition of passives. 

Noun modifier placement. Our study of noun modifier placement (a construction known as left branch extraction, LBE), which is possible in Russian, but not English (“Kakuju on kupil mashinu?” literally [Which he bought car?]) showed that bilingual and monolingual children acquire the feature in the same way. 

We shared our research at 5 scholarly conferences and in one journal paper. In addition to expanding our research on these four projects, we are also investigating negative interrogatives and subjunctives, both of which have different meanings, grammar, and distribution in Russian, English, and German.

In addition to this intellectual merit, the project has broader impacts. Naturally occurring child acquisition data for Russian in this quantity was not previously available publicly; the quantity and quality of our annotation uniquely positions BiRCh as a powerful research tool for researchers investigating the language of immigrant and monolingual Russian communities, language acquisition and maintenance, as well as for practitioners developing language materials and parents raising bilingual children. 

Our code and transcription and annotation guidelines were shared publicly, and multiple members of the scientific community were personally trained by the PI in the use of BiRCh annotation methods. 

This award supported 8 graduate students and 11 undergraduate students including REU participants; some students conducted their own research and are co-authors with the PIs. Undergraduate and graduate students, as well as 13 community research assistants (empowering members of the studied communities)  received training in various scientific techniques employed in this project. Trainees were (78% female) and included people with disabilities and refugees.
